sn36.5:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn36.5:1.4.pli: Sukhā, bhikkhave, vedanā dukkhato daṭṭhabbā, dukkhā vedanā sallato daṭṭhabbā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā aniccato daṭṭhabbā.
sn36.5:1.4.eng: Pleasant feeling should be seen as suffering. Painful feeling should be seen as a dart. Neutral feeling should be seen as impermanent.

sn36.5:1.5.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sukhā vedanā dukkhato diṭṭhā hoti, dukkhā vedanā sallato diṭṭhā hoti, adukkhamasukhā vedanā aniccato diṭṭhā hoti—
sn36.5:1.5.eng: When a mendicant has seen these three feelings in this way,

sn36.5:1.6.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu sammaddaso acchecchi taṇhaṃ, vivattayi saṃyojanaṃ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā’ti.
sn36.5:1.6.eng: they’re called a mendicant who sees rightly, has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.

sn36.5:2.1.eng: A mendicant who sees pleasure as pain,

sn36.5:3.4.eng: they’re without defilements in this very life.

sn36.5:3.5.eng: That knowledge master is firm in principle;

sn36.5:3.6.eng: when their body breaks up, they can’t be reckoned.”

sn36.6:1.1.pli: “Assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano sukhampi vedanaṃ vedayati, dukkhampi vedanaṃ vedayati, adukkhamasukhampi vedanaṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person feels pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.

sn36.6:1.2.pli: Sutavā, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sukhampi vedanaṃ vedayati, dukkhampi vedanaṃ vedayati, adukkhamasukhampi vedanaṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:1.2.eng: A learned noble disciple also feels pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.

sn36.6:1.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ko viseso ko adhippayāso kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanenā”ti?
sn36.6:1.3.eng: What, then, is the difference between a learned noble disciple and an ordinary unlearned person?”

sn36.6:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn36.6:1.5.pli: assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohaṃ āpajjati.
sn36.6:1.5.eng: “When an unlearned ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

sn36.6:1.8.eng: It’s like a person who is struck with an arrow,

sn36.6:1.9.eng: only to be struck with a second arrow.

sn36.6:1.10.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, puriso dvisallena vedanaṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:1.10.eng: That person experiences the feeling of two arrows.

sn36.6:1.11.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohaṃ āpajjati.
sn36.6:1.11.eng: In the same way, when an unlearned ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

sn36.6:1.14.pli: Tassāyeva kho pana dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno paṭighavā hoti.
sn36.6:1.14.eng: When they’re touched by painful feeling, they resist it.

sn36.6:1.15.pli: Tamenaṃ dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighavantaṃ, yo dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo, so anuseti.
sn36.6:1.15.eng: The underlying tendency for repulsion towards painful feeling underlies that.

sn36.6:1.16.pli: So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno kāmasukhaṃ abhinandati.
sn36.6:1.16.eng: When touched by painful feeling they look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures.

sn36.6:1.18.pli: Na hi so, bhikkhave, pajānāti assutavā puthujjano aññatra kāmasukhā dukkhāya vedanāya nissaraṇaṃ,
sn36.6:1.18.eng: Because an unlearned ordinary person doesn’t understand any escape from painful feeling apart from sensual pleasures.

sn36.6:1.19.pli: tassa kāmasukhañca abhinandato, yo sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayo, so anuseti.
sn36.6:1.19.eng: Since they look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures, the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling underlies that.

sn36.6:1.20.pli: So tāsaṃ vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
sn36.6:1.20.eng: They don’t truly understand feelings’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn36.6:1.21.pli: Tassa tāsaṃ vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ appajānato, yo adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo, so anuseti.
sn36.6:1.21.eng: The underlying tendency to ignorance about neutral feeling underlies that.

sn36.6:1.22.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, saññutto naṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:1.22.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it attached.

sn36.6:1.23.pli: Dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, saññutto naṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:1.23.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it attached.

sn36.6:1.24.pli: Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, saññutto naṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:1.24.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it attached.

sn36.6:1.25.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘assutavā puthujjano saññutto jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, saññutto dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn36.6:1.25.eng: They’re called an unlearned ordinary person who is attached to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They are attached to suffering, I say.
sn36.6:1.25.comm: The ablative dukkhasmā here is explained by the commentary as taking an instrumental sense, like the preceding terms.

sn36.6:2.1.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati, na kilamati, na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
sn36.6:2.1.eng: When a learned noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

sn36.6:3.1.eng: It’s like a person who is struck with an arrow,

sn36.6:3.2.pli: Tamenaṃ dutiyena sallena anuvedhaṃ na vijjheyya.
sn36.6:3.2.eng: but was not struck with a second arrow.

sn36.6:3.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, puriso ekasallena vedanaṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:3.3.eng: That person would experience the feeling of one arrow.

sn36.6:3.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati, na kilamati, na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
sn36.6:3.4.eng: In the same way, when a learned noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

sn36.6:3.7.pli: Tassāyeva kho pana dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno paṭighavā na hoti.
sn36.6:3.7.eng: When they’re touched by painful feeling, they don’t resist it.

sn36.6:3.8.pli: Tamenaṃ dukkhāya vedanāya appaṭighavantaṃ, yo dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo, so nānuseti.
sn36.6:3.8.eng: There’s no underlying tendency for repulsion towards painful feeling underlying that.

sn36.6:3.9.pli: So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno kāmasukhaṃ nābhinandati.
sn36.6:3.9.eng: When touched by painful feeling they don’t look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures.

sn36.6:3.11.pli: Pajānāti hi so, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako aññatra kāmasukhā dukkhāya vedanāya nissaraṇaṃ.
sn36.6:3.11.eng: Because a learned noble disciple understands an escape from painful feeling apart from sensual pleasures.

sn36.6:3.12.pli: Tassa kāmasukhaṃ nābhinandato yo sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayo, so nānuseti.
sn36.6:3.12.eng: Since they don’t look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures, there’s no underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling underlying that.

sn36.6:3.13.pli: So tāsaṃ vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavaṃ ca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn36.6:3.13.eng: They truly understand feelings’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn36.6:3.14.pli: Tassa tāsaṃ vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānato, yo adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo, so nānuseti.
sn36.6:3.14.eng: There’s no underlying tendency to ignorance about neutral feeling underlying that.

sn36.6:3.15.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaññutto naṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:3.15.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.

sn36.6:3.16.pli: Dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaññutto naṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:3.16.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.

sn36.6:3.17.pli: Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaññutto naṃ vedayati.
sn36.6:3.17.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.

sn36.6:3.18.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘sutavā ariyasāvako visaññutto jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, visaññutto dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn36.6:3.18.eng: They’re called a learned noble disciple who is detached from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They are detached from suffering, I say.

sn36.6:3.19.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, viseso, ayaṃ adhippayāso, idaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanenāti.
sn36.6:3.19.eng: This is the difference between a learned noble disciple and an unlearned ordinary person.

sn36.6:4.1.eng: A wise and learned person does not not feel
sn36.6:4.1.comm: The text says they “do not feel” the feeling, thus directly contradicting the main theme of the discourse. Bodhi inserts “mental” to resolve this. The commentary does not notice this verse at all, as it only comments on “learned” after “appraised” in the next verse, suggesting that either the verse was inserted after the commentary, or that it posed no interpretive difficulties. The initial line is also metrically imperfect: as a tuṭṭhubha, the final syllable of vedayati should be long; perhaps it was originally the reflexive vedayate. It seems to me the line is corrupt, and the simplest emendation is to assume a double negative that was later omitted; the omission of the negative is attested elsewhere in Pali verse (eg. Snp 3.8:17.4). Or perhaps, without emending, the initial na should be distributed to both noun and verb.

sn36.6:4.2.eng: the feeling of pleasure and pain.

sn36.6:4.3.eng: This is the great difference of skill

sn36.6:4.4.eng: between the wise one and the ordinary.

sn36.6:5.1.eng: A learned person who has appraised the teaching

sn36.6:5.2.eng: discerns this world and the next.

sn36.6:5.3.eng: Desirable things don’t disturb their mind,

sn36.6:5.4.eng: nor are they repelled by the undesirable.

sn36.6:6.2.eng: are cleared and ended, they are no more.

sn36.6:6.4.eng: they who have gone beyond rebirth <j>understand rightly.”

sn36.7:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn36.7:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn36.7:1.1.comm: This discourse shows how a practitioner first develops the four kinds of mindfulness meditation for gaining immersion, along with practicing “situational awareness” (sometimes called “mindfulness in daily life”), before developing insight into the nature of feelings.

sn36.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena gilānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn36.7:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the infirmary, where he sat down on the seat spread out,
sn36.7:1.2.comm: The “infirmary” (gilānasālā) is mentioned only in this discourse and the next, and in AN 5.121. The practice of visiting people when sick to give encouragement and support is still an important part of Buddhist culture.

sn36.7:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
sn36.7:2.1.comm: The same treatment of being “mindful and aware” is at DN 16:2.12.2, SN 47.2, and SN 47.35.

sn36.7:2.2.eng: This is my instruction to you.

sn36.7:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant mindful?
sn36.7:3.1.comm: In the Gradual Training, the mendicant “establishes mindfulness” to begin meditation. Here this practice is expanded, and it is expanded even further in the Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta (MN 10 = DN 22) and the Satipaṭṭhāna Saṁyutta beginning with SN 47.1.

sn36.7:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn36.7:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
sn36.7:3.2.comm: This marks the first appearance of the satipaṭṭhāna formula in the Saṁyutta. Despite the modern perception that satipaṭṭhāna is essentially the practice of insight, it appears nowhere in the great wisdom Saṁyuttas on dependent origination, the aggregates, the senses, or the elements. In the Suttas, satipaṭṭhāna is the support for immersion, with insight emerging from immersion.

sn36.7:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn36.7:3.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …

sn36.7:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn36.7:3.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn36.7:3.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sato hoti.
sn36.7:3.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.

sn36.7:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant aware?

sn36.7:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
sn36.7:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

sn36.7:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajānakārī hoti.
sn36.7:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant acts with situational awareness.

sn36.7:4.4.pli: Sato, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajāno kālaṃ āgameyya.
sn36.7:4.4.eng: A mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.

sn36.7:4.5.eng: This is my instruction to you.

sn36.7:5.1.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṃ satassa sampajānassa appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati sukhā vedanā, so evaṃ pajānāti:
sn36.7:5.1.eng: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if pleasant feelings arise, they understand:

sn36.7:5.2.eng: ‘A pleasant feeling has arisen in me.

sn36.7:5.3.pli: Sā ca kho paṭicca, no appaṭicca.

sn36.7:5.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana kāyo anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.
sn36.7:5.6.eng: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.

sn36.7:5.7.pli: Aniccaṃ kho pana saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ kāyaṃ paṭicca uppannā sukhā vedanā kuto niccā bhavissatī’ti.
sn36.7:5.7.eng: So how could a pleasant feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’

sn36.7:5.8.pli: So kāye ca sukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassī viharati, vayānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
sn36.7:5.8.eng: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and pleasant feeling.

sn36.7:5.9.pli: Tassa kāye ca sukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassino viharato, vayānupassino viharato, virāgānupassino viharato, nirodhānupassino viharato, paṭinissaggānupassino viharato, yo kāye ca sukhāya ca vedanāya rāgānusayo, so pahīyati.
sn36.7:5.9.eng: As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for greed for the body and pleasant feeling.

sn36.7:6.1.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṃ satassa sampajānassa appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati dukkhā vedanā.
sn36.7:6.1.eng: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if painful feelings arise, they understand:

sn36.7:6.3.eng: ‘A painful feeling has arisen in me.

sn36.7:6.4.pli: Sā ca kho paṭicca, no appaṭicca.

sn36.7:6.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana kāyo anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.
sn36.7:6.7.eng: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.

sn36.7:6.8.pli: Aniccaṃ kho pana saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ kāyaṃ paṭicca uppannā dukkhā vedanā kuto niccā bhavissatī’ti.
sn36.7:6.8.eng: So how could a painful feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’

sn36.7:6.9.pli: So kāye ca dukkhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassī viharati, vayānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
sn36.7:6.9.eng: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and painful feeling.

sn36.7:6.10.pli: Tassa kāye ca dukkhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassino viharato …pe… paṭinissaggānupassino viharato, yo kāye ca dukkhāya ca vedanāya paṭighānusayo, so pahīyati.
sn36.7:6.10.eng: As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for repulsion towards the body and painful feeling.

sn36.7:7.1.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṃ satassa sampajānassa appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā, so evaṃ pajānāti:
sn36.7:7.1.eng: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if neutral feelings arise, they understand:

sn36.7:7.2.eng: ‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me.

sn36.7:7.3.pli: Sā ca kho paṭicca, no appaṭicca.

sn36.7:7.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana kāyo anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.
sn36.7:7.6.eng: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.

sn36.7:7.7.pli: Aniccaṃ kho pana saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ kāyaṃ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhā vedanā kuto niccā bhavissatī’ti.
sn36.7:7.7.eng: So how could a neutral feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’

sn36.7:7.8.pli: So kāye ca adukkhamasukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassī viharati, vayānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
sn36.7:7.8.eng: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and neutral feeling.

sn36.7:7.9.pli: Tassa kāye ca adukkhamasukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassino viharato …pe… paṭinissaggānupassino viharato, yo kāye ca adukkhamasukhāya ca vedanāya avijjānusayo, so pahīyati.
sn36.7:7.9.eng: As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for ignorance towards the body and neutral feeling.

sn36.7:8.1.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā aniccāti pajānāti, anajjhositāti pajānāti, anabhinanditāti pajānāti;
sn36.7:8.1.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

sn36.7:8.2.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

sn36.7:8.3.pli: adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā aniccāti pajānāti, anajjhositāti pajānāti, anabhinanditāti pajānāti.
sn36.7:8.3.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

sn36.7:8.4.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaññutto naṃ vedayati;
sn36.7:8.4.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.

sn36.7:8.5.pli: dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaññutto naṃ vedayati;
sn36.7:8.5.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.

sn36.7:8.6.pli: adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaññutto naṃ vedayati.
sn36.7:8.6.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.

sn36.7:8.7.pli: So kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
sn36.7:8.7.eng: Feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn36.7:8.8.pli: ‘Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
sn36.7:8.8.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’

sn36.7:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, telañca paṭicca vaṭṭiñca paṭicca telappadīpo jhāyeyya,
sn36.7:9.1.eng: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.

sn36.7:9.2.pli: tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā anāhāro nibbāyeyya;
sn36.7:9.2.eng: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to not being fed.

sn36.7:9.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. Jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
sn36.7:9.3.eng: In the same way, feeling the end of the body draw close, a mendicant understands: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, a mendicant understands: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn36.7:9.4.pli: ‘Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn36.7:9.4.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’”

sn36.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn36.8:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn36.8:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena gilānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn36.8:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the infirmary, where he sat down on the seat spread out,

sn36.8:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.

sn36.8:2.2.eng: This is my instruction to you.

sn36.8:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant mindful?

sn36.8:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn36.8:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn36.8:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn36.8:3.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …

sn36.8:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn36.8:3.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn36.8:3.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sato hoti.
sn36.8:3.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.

sn36.8:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant aware?

sn36.8:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti …pe… bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
sn36.8:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

sn36.8:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajāno hoti.
sn36.8:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is aware.

sn36.8:4.4.pli: Sato, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajāno kālaṃ āgameyya.
sn36.8:4.4.eng: A mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.

sn36.8:4.5.eng: This is my instruction to you.

sn36.8:5.1.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṃ satassa sampajānassa appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
sn36.8:5.1.eng: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if pleasant feelings arise, they understand:

sn36.8:5.3.eng: ‘A pleasant feeling has arisen in me.

sn36.8:5.4.pli: sā ca kho paṭicca, no appaṭicca.

sn36.8:5.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana phasso anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.
sn36.8:5.7.eng: But this contact is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.

sn36.8:5.8.pli: Aniccaṃ kho pana saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā sukhā vedanā kuto niccā bhavissatī’ti.
sn36.8:5.8.eng: So how could a pleasant feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on contact that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’

sn36.8:5.9.pli: So phasse ca sukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassī viharati, vayānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
sn36.8:5.9.eng: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in contact and pleasant feeling.

sn36.8:5.10.pli: Tassa phasse ca sukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassino viharato, vayānupassino viharato, virāgānupassino viharato, nirodhānupassino viharato, paṭinissaggānupassino viharato yo phasse ca sukhāya ca vedanāya rāgānusayo, so pahīyati.
sn36.8:5.10.eng: As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for greed for contact and pleasant feeling.

sn36.8:6.1.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṃ satassa …pe…
sn36.8:6.1.eng: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if painful feelings arise …

sn36.8:6.3.eng: if neutral feelings arise, they understand:

sn36.8:6.5.eng: ‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me.

sn36.8:6.6.pli: sā ca kho paṭicca, no appaṭicca.

sn36.8:6.9.eng: (Tell in full as in the previous discourse.)

sn36.8:6.10.pli: Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
sn36.8:6.10.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’

sn36.8:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, telañca paṭicca vaṭṭiñca paṭicca telappadīpo jhāyeyya,
sn36.8:7.1.eng: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.

sn36.8:7.2.pli: tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā anāhāro nibbāyeyya;
sn36.8:7.2.eng: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to not being fed.

sn36.8:7.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. Jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
sn36.8:7.3.eng: In the same way, feeling the end of the body draw close, a mendicant understands: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn36.8:7.4.pli: ‘Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn36.8:7.4.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’”

sn36.9:1.1.pli: “Tisso imā, bhikkhave, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā.
sn36.9:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three feelings are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

sn36.9:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.9:1.4.pli: imā kho, bhikkhave, tisso vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā”ti.
sn36.9:1.4.eng: These are the three feelings that are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.”

sn37.1:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato mātugāmo ekantaamanāpo hoti purisassa.
sn37.1:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a lady has five factors she is extremely undesirable to a man.
sn37.1:1.1.comm: Mātugāma literally means “motherkind” (cf. the archaic “motherkin”). It is a word for women in Pali, but it appears unique to Buddhist texts, and hence may be a technical or formal term (cf. puggala, SN 22.22:2.2). Grammatically it is always singular, but it sometimes takes a plural sense as a collective noun. In this sentence, for example, mātugāma is paired with “man” so it must be a singular “woman”, but at SN 37.3:1.1 it is paired with “men” in plural so it must be “womankind” in general. It is not always possible to determine which sense applies. As to the connotations of the term, the commentary says it is any human woman, even one born that very day. Probably the term “mother” is meant in an affectionate and respectful sense, perhaps to remind the monks not to fall into objectification (cf. SN 35.127:1.6). This thesis claims weak support from the observation that throughout the Pātimokkha—the quintessential text for monks—mātugāma is used in apposition with bhikkhu, whereas itthī (“woman”) is used with purisa (“man”). But there is no corresponding male form, so bhikkhunī just takes purisa. However, this distinction does not obtain here, where mātugāma is used with purisa. To suggest this slightly elevated sense, I use “lady” for mātugāma and “woman” for itthī_.

sn37.1:1.3.pli: Na ca rūpavā hoti, na ca bhogavā hoti, na ca sīlavā hoti, alaso ca hoti, pajañcassa na labhati—
sn37.1:1.3.eng: She’s not attractive, wealthy, or ethical; she’s idle, and she doesn’t beget children.

sn37.1:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato mātugāmo ekantaamanāpo hoti purisassa.
sn37.1:1.4.eng: When a lady has these five factors she is extremely undesirable to a man.

sn37.1:1.5.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato mātugāmo ekantamanāpo hoti purisassa.
sn37.1:1.5.eng: When a lady has five factors she is extremely desirable to a man.

sn37.1:1.7.pli: Rūpavā ca hoti, bhogavā ca hoti, sīlavā ca hoti, dakkho ca hoti analaso, pajañcassa labhati—
sn37.1:1.7.eng: She’s attractive, wealthy, and ethical; she’s deft and tireless, and she begets children.

sn37.1:1.8.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato mātugāmo ekantamanāpo hoti purisassā”ti.
sn37.1:1.8.eng: When a lady has these five factors she is extremely desirable to a man.”
sn37.1:1.8.comm: As to why the Buddha should be listing the traits that make a woman desirable, your guess is as good as mine. The next discourse says the exact same thing with genders reversed. Perhaps the purpose was to subvert expectations. One noteworthy detail is that this leaves out questions of caste and family, in contrast with say Manu 3.5–19.

sn37.10:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, anuruddha, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo …pe… nirayaṃ upapajjati.

sn37.10:1.3.pli: Assaddho ca hoti, ahiriko ca hoti, anottappī ca hoti, dussīlo ca hoti, duppañño ca hoti—
sn37.10:1.3.eng: “… They’re faithless, shameless, imprudent, unethical, and witless. …”

sn37.10:1.4.pli: imehi kho, anuruddha, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo …pe… nirayaṃ upapajjatī”ti.

sn37.11:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, anuruddha, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo …pe… nirayaṃ upapajjati.

sn37.11:1.3.pli: Assaddho ca hoti, ahiriko ca hoti, anottappī ca hoti, appassuto ca hoti, duppañño ca hoti—
sn37.11:1.3.eng: “… They’re faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, and witless. …”

sn37.11:1.4.pli: imehi kho, anuruddha, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo …pe… nirayaṃ upapajjatī”ti.

sn37.12:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, anuruddha, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo …pe… nirayaṃ upapajjati.

sn37.12:1.3.pli: Assaddho ca hoti, ahiriko ca hoti, anottappī ca hoti, kusīto ca hoti, duppañño ca hoti—
sn37.12:1.3.eng: “… They’re faithless, shameless, imprudent, lazy, and witless. …”

sn37.12:1.4.pli: imehi kho, anuruddha, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo …pe… apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjatī”ti.

sn37.13:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, anuruddha, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo …pe… nirayaṃ upapajjati.

sn37.13:1.3.pli: Assaddho ca hoti, ahiriko ca hoti, anottappī ca hoti, muṭṭhassati ca hoti, duppañño ca hoti—
sn37.13:1.3.eng: “… They’re faithless, shameless, imprudent, unmindful, and witless. …”

sn37.13:1.4.pli: imehi kho, anuruddha, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo …pe… nirayaṃ upapajjatī”ti.
